Title: High-Density Vertical Organic Electrochemical Transistors: A New Era of Flexible and Stable Electronics

Introduction

Scientists have long been exploring the potential of organic electrochemical transistors (OECTs) due to their unique ability to modulate electrical current in response to minor changes in voltage. These transistors hold great promise for various applications, such as biosensors, wearable devices, and neuromorphic systems. However, several challenges must be addressed before realizing their full potential, primarily related to stability and performance. Recently, researchers from Northwestern University presented an innovative solution to overcome these obstacles using high-density and mechanically flexible OECT arrays.

Advantages and Limitations of Conventional OECTs

Conventional OECTs offer numerous benefits over traditional transistors, such as favorable amplification and sensing capabilities, low driving voltages, and adaptable structural design. Nevertheless, these devices encounter certain drawbacks, like instability and slower redox processes hindering overall efficiency. To tackle these limitations, research efforts focus on enhancing device architecture and improving material quality.

A Novel Fabrication Strategy for High-Performance OECT Arrays

Jaehyun Kim, Robert M. Pankow, and their teammates devised a cutting-edge approach to manufacture high-performance OECT arrays through electron-beam exposure (eBL). By adopting this technique, they managed to achieve densely packed and mechanically pliable vertical OECT arrays capable of creating intricate circuits. The novelty behind this method resides in its maskless patterning capability, eliminating damaging chemicals during production.

The Power of eBL for Multilayered Integration

Employing eBL enables precise control over pattern dimensions, allowing ultra-high density and sharp conducting channels. Furthermore, this technology fosters seamless incorporation of multiple layers required for complex circuitry. As a result, the newly formed p- and n-type vertical OECT arrays display impressive transconductance values ranging between 0.08-1.7 S, fast transient times below 100 μs, and outstanding cycling stability exceeding 100,000 operations.

Demonstrating Real-World Applications

To emphasize their innovation's practical applicability, Kim, Pankow, and collaborators demonstrated the creation of various vertically stacked logic circuits using their advanced OECT arrays. They successfully built NOT, NAND, and NOR gates exhibiting remarkable functionality alongside exceptional operational stability. Such developments highlight the promising future of OECTs in diverse technological domains.

Future Perspectives and Implications

These groundbreaking findings open up exciting avenues for developing next-generation OECTs with enhanced stability and performance features. Additionally, the revolutionary e-beam exposure strategy may lead to large-scale manufacturing techniques, ultimately accelerating the integration of OECTs into real-world electronic devices. Further investigations will undoubtedly unlock additional possibilities for this fascinating field, propelling us towards smarter and more sustainable tech solutions.

Jaehyun Kim et al., Monolithically integrated high-density vertical organic electrochemical transistor arrays and complementary circuits, Nature Electronics (2024). DOI: 10.1038/s41928-024-01127-x

Instagram Reels: A New Feature to Share Short Videos with Friends

Instagram has announced a new feature called Blend, which allows you to share a private collection of Reels with a friend. According to TechCrunch, Blend will be based on Reels you've shared with other people as well as Reels you and a friend both showed interest in. This feature would create a private feed between you and the other person, and either of you could leave it at any time.

To access a Reel, simply tap the Reels icon in the iOS or Android mobile app or on the website. Swipe or scroll up and down to watch each video. With the icons on the right, you can like, comment on, share, or listen to the audio from any Reel. Instagram uses a few different tricks to direct you to Reels you may like. The app suggests Reels liked by someone you follow, Reels you've already watched, and posts you've liked or saved. Resharing a Reel, watching it until the end, or checking out the Reel's page are other signs that you might watch similar Reels.

Instagram Reels: A TikTok-Like Feature

Instagram Reels is a TikTok-like feature that allows users to create and share short, entertaining videos with an audio track and special effects. With a private account, you can share your Reels with just your followers or close friends. With a public account, you can share your Reels for anyone on Instagram to watch.

A feature like Blend could potentially expand the reach and engagement of a Reel by letting two people discover and enjoy the same videos together. Plus, Blend could be another feature that helps Instagram keep up with fellow video sharing platform TikTok, as the two battle for users and advertising dollars.

Instagram Rolls Out New Reels Features

Instagram rolled out several new Reels features last November. You can now share your Reels with just close friends instead of all your followers. To spruce up a video during the editing phase, you can scale, crop, rotate clips, and undo and redo edits.

In conclusion, Instagram's new Blend feature is an exciting addition to the platform's Reels feature. This feature allows users to share a private collection of Reels with a friend, making it easier to discover and enjoy videos together. With the increasing popularity of video sharing platforms, Instagram is continually working to keep up and stay relevant to its users.

post_title: OpenAI's Voice Engine can clone a voice from a 15-second clip. Listen for yourself
title: OpenAI's Voice Engine clones human voice from 15-second sample.
post_content:
As the world of AI continues to evolve, OpenAI remains at the forefront of innovation with cutting-edge technology such as Sora, its impressive text-to-video generator. Recently, the company unveiled insights from a small-scale preview of Voice Engine, a voice cloning AI model that can create realistic, emotive voices using text input and a 15-second audio sample.

The technology is truly remarkable, as seen in the clip below. Voice Engine can generate a highly realistic-sounding voice that closely resembles the voice in the reference clip. It's a feat that raises some serious questions about the potential consequences of having an AI voice generator that can impersonate someone's voice from just a 15-second sample.

OpenAI is aware of these risks and has not yet released Voice Engine to the public. The company's blog post acknowledges the seriousness of the situation, especially in light of an election year. However, OpenAI has been privately testing Voice Engine with a small group of partners to learn more about its potential use cases, safeguards, and other considerations.

The partners testing Voice Engine were required to agree to OpenAI's usage policies, which prohibit them from impersonating an individual or organization without the original speaker's consent. Other safeguards include disclosing to the audience that the voice they hear is AI-generated, adding watermarks that trace back to Voice Engine, monitoring the model's usage, and prohibiting the creation of new voices.

Despite the restrictions, OpenAI's partners have already found use cases for Voice Engine that have the potential to be positive. For example, Age of Learning used the technology to provide non-readers and children with reading assistance by generating pre-scripted voice-over content and personalized responses. HeyGen, an AI avatar-generating startup, built a tool on Voice Engine that translates a speaker's voice into multiple languages.

OpenAI is keeping Voice Engine in preview mode for now, but other similar models are already available to the public. Take ElevenLabs, a startup that has made headlines for both positive and negative use cases of its AI-powered voice-generating platform. The best-known example of ElevenLabs's tech is the recent fake robocall of President Joe Biden that encouraged voters not to show up at the polls.

The ElevenLabs Voice Cloning tool is easy to access and use. You just need an ElevenLabs account, a few minutes of voice samples, and a text prompt.

OpenAI's approach to Voice Engine is smart, as it recognizes the risks associated with voice cloning and is taking steps to ensure its responsible use. However, it's important for the AI industry to continue raising awareness about these risks and emphasizing to users the importance of verifying sources before they believe what they hear and see.

In conclusion, Voice Engine is an impressive piece of technology that has the potential to revolutionize the way we interact with AI. However, it's essential to approach its use with caution and ensure that appropriate safeguards are in place to prevent misuse.

post_title: Google to delete incognito search data to end privacy suit
title: Google to Delete Incognito Search Data; End Privacy Suit settlement
post_content:
Google has recently announced that it is working to replace software cookies that track the internet activity of its Chrome users. This move aims to safeguard people's privacy while still allowing effective targeting of ads. In addition, Google has agreed to delete a vast trove of search data as part of a settlement to resolve a suit that it tracked millions of US users who believed they were browsing the internet privately.

According to the settlement, Google must delete and/or remediate billions of data records linked to people using the Chrome browser's Incognito mode. This is an historic step in requiring dominant technology companies to be honest in their representations to users about how they collect and employ user data. The settlement calls for no cash damages to be paid but leaves an option for Chrome users who feel they were wronged to sue Google separately to get money.

The lawsuit originally filed in June of 2020 sought at least $5 billion in damages. The object of the lawsuit was the "Incognito Mode" in the Chrome browser that plaintiffs said gave users a false sense that what they were surfing online was not being tracked by the Silicon Valley tech firm. However, internal Google emails brought forward in the lawsuit demonstrated that users using incognito mode were being followed by the search and advertising behemoth for measuring web traffic and selling ads.

The lawsuit claimed that Google's practices infringed on users' privacy by intentionally deceiving them with the incognito option. The original complaint alleged that Google had been given the "power to learn intimate details about individuals' lives, interests, and internet usage."

To address this issue, the settlement requires Google to block third-party tracking "cookies" by default in Incognito Mode for the next five years. Third-party cookies are small files that are used to target advertising by tracking web navigation and are placed by visited sites and not by the browser itself.

Google earlier this year began limiting third-party cookies for some users of its Chrome browser, a first step towards eventually abandoning the files that have raised privacy concerns. Google announced in January 2020 that it would begin eliminating third-party cookies within two years, but the start has been delayed several times amid opposition from web media publishers.

Cookies have recently been subject to greater regulation, including the European Union's General Data Protection Regulation introduced in 2016 as well as regulations in California.

In conclusion, Google's move to replace software cookies with a more privacy-focused approach is a positive step towards safeguarding users' privacy while still allowing effective targeting of ads. The settlement to resolve the suit that tracked millions of US users who believed they were browsing the internet privately is also a historic step in requiring dominant technology companies to be honest in their representations to users about how they collect and employ user data. The requirement to block third-party tracking "cookies" by default in Incognito Mode for the next five years is a step towards eventually abandoning the files that have raised privacy concerns and will help to protect users' privacy in the future.

post_title: When Gmail arrived 20 years ago, people thought it was an April Fools prank
title: In the 20 years since its launch, Gmail has become the go-to email service for millions of people. Its groundbreaking features like unlimited storage and search have made it a favorite among users, and its constant updates and additions have ensured it remains relevant and useful today. Despite controversy and changes in communication habits, Gmail remains a reliable and effective tool for email communication.
post_content:
In the annals of technology history, Gmail's launch on April 1, 2004, will undoubtedly be remembered as a pivotal moment. At the time, Google's announcement of its own email platform was met with skepticism, as many believed it to be an April Fool's Day prank. However, as it turned out, Gmail was far from a joke.

Google's advertised 1 GB of free storage was a staggering amount for the time, dwarfing email alternatives like Hotmail and Yahoo, which offered a mere fraction of that amount. Fast forward to 2021, and Gmail is not only still going strong but has become the undisputed king of email with 1.2 billion users under its belt. And with a storage limit of up to 15 GB per user, Gmail has come a long way since its humble beginnings.

In the original press release, Google highlighted the ability to search for a specific message, a groundbreaking feature at the time, and the unprecedented storage space. "Gmail is built on the idea that users should never have to file or delete a message or struggle to find an email they've sent or received," the press release read.

Over the years, Gmail has continued to evolve and add new features to make emailing easier and more efficient. In 2005, Google doubled its available storage size to 2 GB per user, and in 2006, it launched the companion Google Calendar. Google Chat was introduced the same year, and the service went fully public on February 14, 2007.

In 2008, Gmail saw the addition of perhaps its most useful feature -- the forgotten attachment detector, followed by the much-needed "undo send" in 2009. The same year saw offline access added, and the service continued to grow, adding an iOS app in 2011. In 2012, Gmail saw an upgrade to 10 GB of storage, and by 2013, the storage limit had reached its current 15 GB limit.

Small features have been added through the years, like smart replies, one-click unsubscribe, an integrated view that makes it easier to move between Google apps, and even automatic translation capability and AI features that can write messages for you.

Despite its popularity, Gmail's time hasn't been without controversy. Prior to 2017, Google's email service automatically scanned the text of each message not only to detect spam or malware but to place relevant advertising alongside. After facing several lawsuits around that practice, particularly concerning matters of race, religion, health, finances, or sexual orientation, Google announced it would stop reading users' emails and use other data sources for contextual ads.

Additionally, a 2018 report from the Wall Street Journal revealed that third-party developers were able to scan hundreds of millions of user emails.

For the most part, though, the service has been the gold standard for email for many years now, and the go-to option for most people.

So, what's the future for Gmail? As an elder millennial on the cusp of Generation X and a Gmail user from the beta days, I remember when email was the main method of communication with far-flung friends and family. But now, with the proliferation of apps like Slack and Teams for work and Messenger and WhatsApp for conversations, I can't remember the last time I used email for actual communication with someone.

Even official things like plane tickets or hotel reservations, for which Gmail used to be my repository, are now accessed through apps. However, for record-keeping, email remains my standard. And of course, email isn't limited to a single platform, as you can still easily access anyone with an email address. Email is better for large mailing lists, and for sending documents and other files, and it's more secure than most messaging apps.

Communication has certainly changed in the two decades since Gmail came onto the scene, and while the purpose of email has changed, it's clear it isn't going anywhere.

TechCrunch is launching a series of interviews focusing on remarkable women who have contributed to the AI revolution. In this piece, we will profile Urvashi Aneja, the founding director of Digital Futures Lab, an interdisciplinary research effort that examines the interaction between technology and society in the Global South.

Body:

Urvashi Aneja is an AI researcher and policy expert based in India. She has a PhD in Sociology from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign and has been a research fellow at the University of California, Berkeley, and the University of Technology, Sydney. Her work focuses on the impact of technology on society and the use of AI in India.

Aneja's most recent research focuses on the societal impact of algorithmic decision-making systems in India. She has authored several studies on the use of AI in India across various sectors, including policing and agriculture.

One of Aneja's most significant contributions to the field of AI is her work on the political economy of AI production and its broader implications for social justice, labor relations, and environmental sustainability. She has also developed procurement guidelines for AI use in the public sector and delivered evidence in legal proceedings against Big Tech companies in the Global South.

Aneja navigates the challenges of the male-dominated tech industry by letting her work do the talking and constantly asking "why?" She advises women seeking to enter the AI field to develop their knowledge and expertise by making sure their technical understanding of issues is sound, but not narrowly focused only on AI.

Some of the most pressing issues facing AI as it evolves include the concentration of power within a handful of technology companies, the need for institutional development needed to develop safeguards, and the environmental impacts of AI. Aneja advises users to be aware that AI is not magic and that it's a form of computational statistics that has many beneficial uses, but is ultimately only a probabilistic guess based on historical or previous patterns.

Conclusion:

Urvashi Aneja's work on the societal impact of AI in India highlights the importance of considering the broader implications of AI on society. Her advice to women seeking to enter the AI field emphasizes the need for a holistic understanding of technology and its impact on society. As AI continues to evolve, it's crucial that we remain aware of the challenges it presents and work to address them.

post_content:
OpenAI CEO Sam Altman has officially transferred formal control of the company's corporate venture fund, the OpenAI Startup Fund, to Ian Hathaway. This move reflects the company's commitment to maintaining a smooth transition following Altman's brief ouster in November.

Initially, Altman was named as the controller of the fund, but this was intended as a temporary arrangement. Altman made no personal investment, nor did he have any financial interest, a spokesperson stated. However, his involvement in the fund's success is undeniable, as he played a key role in managing the fund and leading investments in several successful startups.

Hathaway, who joined OpenAI in 2021, has been instrumental in managing the Startup Fund's investments in companies like Ambience Healthcare, Cursor, Harvey, and Speak. Before joining OpenAI, he was an investor with Haystack.

Last year, the fund had $175 million in commitments, and now holds $325 million in gross net asset value, according to an SEC filing. The unit invests in early-stage AI-driven companies in fields like healthcare, law, and education.

The Startup Fund has backed at least 16 other startups, according to PitchBook data. These include Descript, a collaborative editing platform valued at $553 million last year, and Ghost Autonomy, which develops software for autonomous driving.

Altman's transfer of formal control to Hathaway signifies a new chapter in the company's journey and a reaffirmation of its commitment to fostering the growth of the AI industry. With Hathaway's expertise and experience, the Startup Fund is well-positioned to continue its mission of investing in promising AI-driven startups and driving innovation in the field.

Title: Revolutionizing Optoelectronics: High-κ 2D Perovskite Oxide as a Photoactive Gate Dielectric

Introduction

In the quest for miniaturized optoelectronic devices that consume less power yet deliver superior performance, scientists have turned their attention towards two-dimensional (2D) superconducting materials. However, achieving high gate capacitance in these small devices poses a significant challenge. This issue can be addressed by using insulating materials with a high dielectric constant (κ); unfortunately, integrating these materials with 2D semiconductors has proven to be difficult. Researchers from Fudan University have made a breakthrough in preparing a 2D perovskite oxide with high-κ that can seamlessly integrate with diverse 2D channel materials. This discovery could revolutionize the future scaling of optoelectronics.

A Novel Approach to Boost Gate Capacitance

Conventional three-dimensional dielectrics face integration difficulties when working with 2D materials featuring dangling-bond-free surfaces. Recognizing this limitation, the research team led by Siyuan Li and Xinya Liu focused on the 2D perovskite oxide Sr₂Nb₃O₁₀, which shows exceptional potential due to its high dielectric constant (κ=24.6) and moderate bandgap. By employing a top-down preparation strategy, the team successfully synthesized SNO nanosheets and subsequently transferred them onto various 2D materials.

Advantageous Characteristics of Sr₂Nb₃O₁₀

The unique properties of Sr₂Nb₃O₁₀ render it an ideal candidate for application in phototransistors based on multiple 2D semiconducting materials, such as graphene, molybdenum disulfide (MoS₂), tungsten disulfide (WS₂), and tungsten diselenide (WSe₂). Its high κ and moderate bandgap facilitate effective photoelectric conversion, ultimately enhancing the efficiency of the resulting devices.

Performance Evaluation of Synthesized 2D Perovskite Oxide

To assess the applicability of their synthesized 2D perovskite oxide in the development of compact optoelectronics, the researchers integrated it with numerous channel materials like MoS₂ and WS₂ before evaluating the performance of the resultant transistors. Impressive results included an on/off ratio of 10⁶ in molybdenum disulfide transistors operating at a low supply voltage of 2 V and a subthreshold swing of 88 mV dec⁻¹. Furthermore, tungsten disulfide phototransistors demonstrated a photocurrent-to-dark-current ratio of approximately 10⁶ and outstanding ultraviolet (UV) responsivity of 5.5 × 10³ A W⁻¹ under both visible and UV light illumination.

Promising Outcomes and Future Prospects

The preliminary outcomes reported by this group of researchers indicate successful integration of their perovskite oxide with various channel materials through a facile method. Additionally, the well-defined interface between the semiconductor and dielectric, coupled with the high-κ of Sr₂Nb₃O₁₀, enables efficient gate control of channel materials. Consequently, phototransistors equipped with this photoactive dielectric material can achieve UV-visible dual-band photodetection—distinguishing UV and visible light illumination at distinct terminals.

Li, Liu, and their collaborators believe that their groundbreaking work will catalyze further exploration into the synthesis of additional 2D perovskite oxides capable of being integrated with existing semiconductors and channel materials. Such advancements would contribute significantly to creating smaller, high-performing, and energy-efficient electronic and optoelectronic systems.

The Limitations of Current AI in Stock Valuation

To test the proficiency of AI in stock valuation, we presented several AI models available in OpenAI's GPT marketplace with a straightforward question: What is the most expensive tech stock? The results were less than impressive. The most common valuation metric is the price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio, which is calculated by dividing the market value per share by the EPS. A high P/E ratio could indicate that a stock is overpriced, but it could also mean that the market expects high growth for the company.

The AI models' inability to comprehend this basic concept is concerning. The failure of AI models to grasp a basic concept like stock valuation has significant implications for the use of AI in stock picking. If AI models cannot answer a simple question about stock valuation, they are unlikely to provide valuable insights for investment decisions.

post_title: The AltStore, an alternative app store coming to the EU, will offer Patreon-backed apps
title: EU’s Digital Markets Act Brings Alt App Store Competition
post_content:
Apple's dominance in the iPhone app store market has long been a cause for concern, with many arguing that it stifles competition and innovation. The European Union's Digital Markets Act (DMA) has finally forced the tech giant to open up its ecosystem to new rivals, and we're beginning to see what an app store environment could look like when developers are allowed to compete.
One such developer is Riley Testut, who has created an alternative app store called the AltStore. This app store will utilize the APIs and frameworks introduced by the DMA to allow developers to distribute apps independently of the App Store, and it's already begun offering a selection of apps to users in the EU.
The AltStore's business model differs from Apple's in-app subscriptions in that it allows developers to use Patreon integration to market their apps directly to consumers. This means that developers can monetize their apps without relying on ads, paid downloads, or in-app purchases.
In addition to offering a new way to monetize apps, the AltStore provides users with a "granular view" of the entitlements that an app has before they install it. This means that users have more control over what apps are installed on their devices, which can help to address some of the security concerns associated with sideloading apps.
While the AltStore is still in its early stages, it's already shown promise as a viable alternative to Apple's dominant app store. It's likely that we'll see more alternative app stores emerge in the coming years, as the DMA continues to force Apple to open up its ecosystem to competition.

Title: Astra's Failed Launch Attempt: From Catastrophe to Acquisition



Back in March 2020, a dramatic event unfolded at Alaska's Pacific Spaceport Complex involving Astra's Rocket 3.0. An "anomaly" – a term used in the industry to refer to any unexpected occurrence – resulted in a fiery explosion prior to the anticipated launch. This incident marked Astra's third attempted orbital launch, yet unfortunately, the vehicle didn't make it past the launchpad.

When the incident happened, Astra remained composed amidst the setback. Having recently emerged from stealth mode, the company held a strong belief in their ability to manufacture rockets rapidly and affordably, accepting a level of failure as part of their strategy. As Astra's CEO, Chris Kemp, stated in a May 2022 interview, "what Astra has to do...is have so many launches that nobody thinks about it anymore." At the time, the ultimate objective wasn't centered around achieving 100% reliability.

Despite experiencing several hiccups along the way, including the 2020 mishap, Astra managed to secure orbit successfully in both November 2021 and March 2022. However, investor enthusiasm began to wane due to unmet expectations regarding cost reduction and escalating financial losses. Ultimately, these challenges led to Astra being acquired through a quiet take-private agreement between Kemp, Chief Technology Officer (CTO) Adam London, and the board. This decision came at a stock price of merely $0.50 per share, far below its peak evaluation. Once the transaction concludes later this quarter, Astra will stop trading on the Nasdaq.

Throughout this journey, Astra showcased resilience and adaptability in overcoming adversities, even if initial objectives weren't fully realized. Although they fell short of revolutionizing the space industry with ultra-low-cost launch plans, valuable lessons were undoubtedly learned, paving the path towards future innovations in the field.
